name: stop to stop st that is happening

children.name: to make st stop happening or continuing
stop
children.definition: /stɒpǁstɑːp/  to make someonestopdoing something, or make something stop happening:kết thúc, chấm dứt, ngăn lại
examples: ▪ the referee stopped the fight when one of the boxers was badly injured.
▪ it is now time to stop the war and begin negotiations for peace.
▪ officials are planning to take court action to stop publication of the book.
stop somebody doing something: ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
▪ i gave my little brother some chocolate to stop him crying.

children.name: put an end to
children.definition: /ˌpʊt ən ˈend tuː/  to stop something, especially so that it never starts again:kết thúc, chấm dứt
examples: ▪ an injury like this could put an end to her dancing career.
▪ the outbreak of war put an end to their romance.

children.name: bring to an end
children.definition: /ˌbrɪŋ tʊ ən ˈend/  to finally and permanently end something that has continued for a long time:chấm dứt (sau một khoảng thời gian dài)
examples: bring something to an end: chấm dứt cái gì
▪ a treaty was signed which finally brought the conflict to an end.
bring to an end something: chấm dứt cái gì
▪ there are calls for the prime minister to bring to an end the uncertainty about the election date.

children.name: halt
children.definition: /hɔːlt/  to make something stop changing, developing, or progressing:tạm nghỉ, tạm dừng
examples: ▪ the government is determined to halt the trade in illegal animal furs.
▪ all his efforts had failed to halt the increase in street crime.

children.name: call off
children.definition: /ˌkɔːl ˈɒf/  to decide that a planned action or activity should be stopped after it has already started:hủy
examples: ▪ the union decided to call off the strike when they were offered a 10% pay rise
.▪ the meeting was called off at the last minute.
▪ the hunt for the missing boy had to be called off because of severe weather conditions.

children.name: cut short
children.definition: /ˌkʌt ˈʃɔːʳt/  to stop an activity earlier than was planned, especially because of something unexpected such as illness or bad news:cắt bớt, rút ngắn
examples: ▪ she was forced to cut short her holiday and return to the uk.
▪ his education was cut short when his father died of a sudden illness.

children.name: abort
children.definition: /əˈbɔːʳt/  to stop an action that has been started, because it would be too dangerous to continue:hủy bỏ
examples: ▪ the mission was aborted after news came of the capture of the city.
▪ the plane had already started its descent when the pilot received orders to abort his landing.

children.name: suspend
children.definition: /səˈspend/  to officially order that something should be stopped, when you intend to let it start again at a later time:đình chỉ, hoãn
examples: ▪ we have decided to suspend all production at the factory until safety checks can be carried out.
▪ all pay increases are to be suspended until further notice.
▪ the trial was suspended after threats were made against witnesses.
suspension/səˈspenʃən/ [uncountable noun]sự đình chỉ, sự tạm hoãn
suspend of: đình chỉ/tạm hoãn cái gì
▪ the president has announced the suspension of all military action in the region.

children.name: pull the plug on
children.definition: /ˌpʊl ðə ˈplʌg ɒn/  informal to stop giving money to a plan or planned business activity so that it cannot continue:hủy bỏ, đình chỉ, ngưng một chương trình, một dự án
examples: ▪ the city council has pulled the plug on the new housing development
.▪ over 1000 workers lost their jobs when the company pulled the plug on plans to open ten new stores.

children.name: freeze
children.definition: /friːz/  to keep prices or wages at the same level and not increase them:làm ổn định, hạn định
examples: ▪ the company has announced that it intends to freeze all salaries for a year.
▪ all government employees have had their salaries frozen at last year’s levels.
freeze[countable noun usually singular]sự ổn định
▪ the prime minister has announced a freeze on income tax for two years.

children.name: to stop st bad or illegal that people are doing
stop
children.definition: /stɒpǁstɑːp/ ngừng
examples: ▪ we must take action to stop this illegal trade in ivory.
▪ all the staff are determined to stop bullying in the school.
stop somebody from doing something: ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
▪ the new measures are intended to stop troublemakers from travelling abroad to football matches.

children.name: put a stop to
children.definition: /ˌpʊt ə ˈstɒp tuːǁ-ˈstɑːp-/  to stop an activity, especially one that you consider to be harmful or unacceptable:ngăn chặn
examples: ▪ using children in this way is pure exploitation, and it’s time we put a stop to it!
▪ she knew that if she didn’t put a stop to their squabbling now, it could go on for weeks.

children.name: stamp out
children.definition: /ˌstæmp ˈaʊt/  to completely stop an illegal or harmful activity:ngăn cản (hành vi trái pháp luật)
examples: ▪ the police have introduced new measures to help stamp out violence on the city’s streets.
▪ we are determined to stamp out prostitution in this neighborhood.

children.name: crack down on
children.definition: /ˌkræk ˈdaʊn ɒn/  to take severe action to stop an illegal activity:ngăn cản những hoạt động phạm pháp
examples: ▪ the authorities are determined to crack down on terrorism.
▪ teachers must crack down on bullying as soon as they become aware of it.
▪ only by cracking down on dealers, can we stop young people getting involved with drugs.
crack-down/ˈkræk daʊn/ [countable noun]
crack down on
▪ davies was eventually caught during a government crack-down on tax evasion.

children.name: call a halt to
children.definition: /ˌkɔːl ə ˈhɔːlt tuː/  to officially order that an activity should be stopped, especially after it has continued for a long time:ra lệnh ngừng lại
examples: ▪ the government has called a halt to the exporting of live animals.
▪ companies must call a halt to the dumping of toxic waste at sea.

children.name: clamp down on
children.definition: /ˌklæmp ˈdaʊn ɒn/  if someone in authorityclamps downonan activity or group of people, they take firm action to stop something that is illegal or against the rules:thực hiện ngăn chặn
examples: ▪ the new, tougher laws are intended clamp down on the carrying of knives and other weapons.
▪ if we don’t clamp down on these troublemakers now, the situation could get out of control.
clampdown /ˈklæmpdaʊn/ [countable noun usually singular]sự ngăn chặn
clamp down on: thực hiện việc ngăn chặn
▪ police say the clampdown on drink-driving has been highly successful.
▪ the new administration has promised a clampdown on corruption.

children.name: curb
children.definition: /kɜːʳb/  to prevent something harmful from increasing and start to control and reduce it:ngăn lại
examples: ▪ the only way to curb the spread of the disease is by immunizing the entire population
.▪ the government is introducing new measures aimed at curbing inflation.

children.name: to stop st quickly before it has time to develop
nip st in the bud
children.definition: nip something in the bud/ˌnɪp something ɪn ðə ˈbʌd/  to stop a bad situation or bad behaviour when it first starts, before it can develop further:ngăn chặn một việc gì
examples: ▪ if i’d known about their plan i could have nipped it in the bud there and then.
it’s important to nip this problem in the bud.

children.name: squash
children.definition: /skwɒʃǁskwɑːʃ, skwɔːʃ/  to quickly stop something such as opposition to your plans that is likely to cause you trouble:nhanh chóng đàn áp, đập tan
examples: and’s claims on her property.
squash a rumour: dập tan tin đồn
▪ the chairman acted quickly to squash rumours of a takeover bid.

children.name: kill
children.definition: /kɪl/  to stop something quickly and completely:giết chết (ngừng lại)
examples: ▪ losing funding now would kill the project
.▪ mr howard released a statement in an effort to kill speculation in the press.

children.name: to stop opposition to a government
suppress
children.definition: /səˈpres/  to stop people opposing or fighting against the government, by using military force or by making their activities illegal:đàn áp, bãi bỏ
examples: ▪ the army acted swiftly to suppress the uprising.
▪ any opposition to the regime is ruthlessly suppressed.
▪ the authorities suppressed publication of the journal.

children.name: put down
children.definition: /ˌpʊt ˈdaʊn/ dập tắt
examples: put down a revolt/rebellion/uprising etc: dập tắt cuộc nổi dậy/ nổi loạn/...
to stop it by using military force against the people involved:
▪ the uprising was quickly put down.
▪ the rebellion was put down and its leaders were executed.

children.name: break up
children.definition: /ˌbreɪk ˈʌp/  if the police or army break up something such as an organized protest, they use force to stop it:giải tán
examples: break up something: giải tán cái gì
▪ the police were instructed to break up the demonstration and arrest the ringleaders.
break something up: giải tán cái gì
▪ the protest continued peacefully until government troops moved in to break it up.

children.name: subdue
children.definition: /səbˈdjuːǁ-ˈduː/  to take action to stop people behaving in a violent, angry way, especially by using force:khuất phục
examples: ▪ the soldiers managed to subdue the angry crowd.
▪ the army has been used to subdue unrest in the country’s capital.

children.name: crush
children.definition: /krʌʃ/  to use severe methods to stop people who are fighting or opposing you:dẹp tan
examples: ▪ the rebellion was quickly crushed by forces loyal to the president.
▪ the army is stationed near the capital, ready to crush any signs of a revolt.

children.name: quell
children.definition: /kwel/  especiallywrittento make violent opposition stop by using force when it first starts, before it becomes impossible to control:đàn áp, dập tắt, dẹp yên
examples: ▪ extra police were called in to quell the disturbance.
▪ an anti-government riot was promptly quelled by soldiers using guns and teargas.

children.name: to stop normal work or services from continuing
paralyse
children.definition: british alsoparalyzeamerican /ˈpærəlaɪz/  to make it impossible for an industry, system, service etc to continue working normally:làm tê liệt
examples: ▪ strike action has paralysed the region’s public transport system.
▪ over illinois, the storm broke, paralyzing the state with blizzards and freezing temperatures.

children.name: bring something to a standstill
children.definition: /ˌbrɪŋ something tʊ ə ˈstændstɪl/  to make it impossible for an industry, system, service etc to continue working normally:bế tắc
examples: ▪ unexpected bad weather has brought london to a standstill.
▪ further interest rate rises may bring the manufacturing industry to a standstill.
▪ rail services have been brought to a standstill by severe flooding in many areas.
bring something to a virtual standstill: trở nên bế tắc
▪ traffic was brought to a virtual standstill as protestors drove in convoy along the motorways.

children.name: end
children.definition: /end/ chấm dứt, kết thúc
examples: ▪ the affair ended after it was made public by the newspapers
.▪ our relationship just isn’t working. i’ve decided to end it.
end[singular noun]sự chấm dứt
▪ we had a huge row, which marked the end of our friendship.

children.name: break off
children.definition: /ˌbreɪk ˈɒf/  to end a relationship or connection with someone, especially an official one:dừng lại, chấm dứt
examples: ▪ the senator has been urged to break off all links with arms companies.
▪ in the wake of the bombing, the uk is threatening to break off diplomatic relations.
▪ his girlfriend has just told him that she wants to break off their engagement.

children.name: sever
children.definition: /ˈsevəʳ/  formal:cách đứt, chia rẻ
examples: sever ties/links/relations etc: cắt đứt mối liên lạc/liên kết/quan hệ
to completely end your relationship or connection with someone or something:
▪ since the job required that he be politically neutral, he had to sever his links with the socialist party.
▪ britain immediately severed relations with the three countries involved.

children.name: to end the use of a system, service, or organization
phase out
children.definition: /ˌfeɪz ˈaʊt/  to gradually end the use of a system, product, or service: dần chấm dứt
examples: phase out something: dần kết thúc cái gì
▪ ministers agreed to phase out the old voting system within two years.
▪ older prisons will be phased out over the next few years.
phase something out: dần chấm dứt cái gì
▪ the committee acknowledged that these chemicals are highly dangerous, and agreed to phase them out gradually.

children.name: discontinue
children.definition: /ˌdɪskənˈtɪnjuː/  to stop providing something that has been available or provided regularly over a period of time:ngừng
examples: ▪ doctors decided to discontinue the treatment when it became clear that the boy had no chance of recovering.
▪ if fewer than ten students sign up, the course will be discontinued.

children.name: a process that cannot be stopped
unstoppable
children.definition: /ʌnˈstɒpəbəlǁ-ˈstɑːp-/  a process or action that isunstoppablecannot be stopped:không thể ngăn cản
examples: ▪ political change is now unstoppable, and the regime will eventually collapse.
▪ the war could unleash unstoppable political and economic changes
.▪ her rise to fame seems to be unstoppable.

children.name: remorseless
children.definition: /rɪˈmɔːʳsləs/  a process that isremorselesscontinues in an unpleasant and threatening way and it seems to be impossible to stop:không chùn bước, không yếu đi
examples: ▪ the remorseless spread of the virus has led to the deaths of thousands.
▪ the remorseless advance of the invading army
remorselessly[adverb]một cách liên tục
▪ the destruction of the rainforests has gone on remorselessly for the past 30 years.

children.name: inexorable
children.definition: /ɪnˈeksərəbəl/  formal use this about a gradual process that cannot be stopped, especially one which leads to something very bad happening:không thể lay động
examples: ▪ his jealousy sets him on an inexorable course towards murder
.▪ the inexorable decline in britain’s manufacturing industry
inexorably[adverb]một cách không thể lay động
▪ the story moves inexorably towards its tragic climax.

children.name: irreversible
children.definition: /ˌɪrɪˈvɜːʳsɪbəl, ˌɪrɪˈvɜːʳsəbəl/  a process of change that isirreversiblecannot be stopped, and the situation that existed before cannot return:không thể đảo ngược lại
examples: ▪ new technology has brought about irreversible changes in society.
▪ despite claims made by skincare manufacturers, the effects of ageing are irreversible.
